**Overview:** Wastewater reuse for agriculture, forestry, and aquaculture is widely practiced, especially in the global South, where untreated or partially treated wastewater is used on a much larger scale than treated wastewater. [Source 1]

**Key Points:**
• The reuse of raw or diluted wastewater for irrigating field crops occurs on up to 35 million hectares around cities in the global South. [Source 1]
• Most of this irrigation relies on untreated or only partially treated wastewater, at a scale thirty times larger than areas using treated wastewater. [Source 1]
• Research and publications highlight practices, safe reuse, and perspectives for wastewater irrigation, including case studies from regions like Mexico and the Middle East. [Source 2]
• Specific regional analyses, such as in the Middle East and North Africa, document the progression of water reuse from principle to practice. [Source 3]

**Implications:**
• There is a significant gap between the widespread use of untreated wastewater and the safer application of treated wastewater, highlighting a major public health and environmental challenge.
• Documented cases from various regions provide valuable lessons for developing safer reuse protocols and policies.

| **Aspect** | **Scale/Detail** |
|------------|------------------|
| Global South Irrigation Area | Up to 35 million hectares [Source 1] |
| Treated vs. Untreated Use | Untreated wastewater use is 30x larger [Source 1] |

Would you like to explore specific health risks associated with untreated wastewater use or the policies promoting safer reuse practices?

references.page_content: Reuse of raw or diluted wastewater for irrigation of ﬁeld crops is practiced around most cities of the global South on a total area of up to 35 million hectares (Raschid-Sally and Jayakody, 2008; Thebo et al., 2017). Most of this irrigation is using untreated or at best partially treated wastewater, at a thirty times larger scale than the known areas using treated wastewater (Scott et al., 2010); Thebo et al., 2017.
